Species-area curves (B) confound area and fragmentation. Correlational approaches (C) cannot establish causation. Before-after road studies (D) confound fragmentation with disturbance.

questions.question: A 50-year dataset from a temperate forest shows: average spring temperature increased by 2.1°C, first leaf-out date advanced by 12 days, first autumn frost date delayed by 8 days, but annual tree growth (ring width) showed no significant change. Which explanation BEST accounts for the lack of growth increase despite the longer growing season?
options: Trees in this forest are at their maximum genetically determined growth rate and cannot grow faster regardless of conditions
Summer drought stress has intensified due to warming, offsetting the gains from a longer growing season through mid-season water limitation
Increased herbivory from expanding insect populations due to warmer winters is consuming the additional growth
Soil nutrient depletion over 50 years has progressively limited growth regardless of growing season length
questions.explanation: The paradox of longer growing seasons without increased tree growth is increasingly documented and is best explained by intensified summer drought stress. Warmer temperatures increase evapotranspiration demand, and earlier spring leaf-out depletes soil moisture reserves sooner. By mid-summer, trees experience water stress that triggers stomatal closure, reducing photosynthesis and limiting growth during what should be the most productive months. In many temperate forests, the net effect is that gains from earlier spring growth are offset by losses from summer drought, resulting in no net change in annual growth. This illustrates how multiple environmental factors interact: climate warming creates both a longer growing season (positive for growth) and greater water stress (negative for growth), with the net effect depending on the balance between these competing influences.

questions.question: Phenological shifts due to climate change are documented across many taxa. Why are phenological mismatches between trophic levels particularly concerning?
options: Phenological changes occur at the same rate across all trophic levels

Different trophic levels may shift phenology at different rates—for example, if plants flower earlier in response to warming but their specialist pollinators emerge based on different cues (photoperiod vs. temperature), the temporal overlap between flower availability and pollinator activity decreases, reducing reproductive success for both partners
Phenology has no effect on species interactions
All organisms respond to climate change by shifting their range, not their phenology
questions.explanation: Phenological mismatches threaten species interactions across ecosystems: (1) Mechanism: Different species use different environmental cues to time life-history events. Temperature-responsive species (many plants, ectotherms) advance phenology with warming, while photoperiod-responsive species (many birds, mammals) do not—creating asynchrony. (2) Classic example: Great tits (Parus major) in the Netherlands time breeding to coincide with peak caterpillar availability. Caterpillar phenology (temperature-cued) has advanced faster than tit breeding (partially photoperiod-cued), reducing synchrony between chick demand and food peak. (3) Plant-pollinator mismatches: Early-flowering plants may bloom before their pollinators are active, reducing pollination success and pollinator food availability. (4) Marine mismatches: Phytoplankton blooms shifting relative to zooplankton reproduction can cascade through marine food webs. (5) Fitness consequences: Mismatches can reduce reproductive success, body condition, and population growth rates for affected species. (6) Not all mismatches are harmful—some species may benefit from extended growing seasons or reduced competition. The net effect on community structure depends on the web of phenological interactions.

questions.question: The global pattern of biomes is primarily determined by climate, particularly temperature and precipitation. Which physical phenomenon is MOST responsible for creating the major deserts at approximately 30°N and 30°S latitude?
options: The tilt of Earth's rotational axis creating seasonal extremes
Hadley cell circulation where dry air descends at subtropical latitudes after rising and losing moisture at the equator
Rain shadow effects from major mountain ranges at these latitudes
Ocean currents that bring cold, dry water to subtropical coasts
questions.explanation: Major subtropical deserts (Sahara, Arabian, Sonoran, Kalahari, Australian) occur at ~30° latitude due to the descending limb of the Hadley cell circulation. At the equator, intense solar heating causes air to rise, cool, and release moisture as tropical rainfall. This now-dry air flows poleward at high altitude and descends at ~30° latitude, warming adiabatically as it descends. The resulting warm, dry air creates high-pressure zones with minimal precipitation. While rain shadows and cold ocean currents (e.g., Humboldt, Benguela) contribute to aridity in specific locations, the Hadley cell is the primary global mechanism creating the subtropical desert belt.

questions.question: The theory of island biogeography (MacArthur and Wilson) predicts that the number of species on an island represents a dynamic equilibrium between immigration and extinction rates. Which prediction of this theory has been MOST consistently supported by empirical data?
options: Larger islands have more species due to lower extinction rates and higher immigration rates
Islands closer to the mainland have more species due to higher immigration rates
Both island area and distance from mainland significantly predict species richness, with area typically being the stronger predictor
Species turnover (replacement of extinct species by new immigrants) occurs at rates predicted by the equilibrium model
questions.explanation: The equilibrium theory of island biogeography predicts that species richness is determined by the balance between immigration (influenced by island distance from source pool) and extinction (influenced by island area). Empirical studies consistently support that both area and isolation significantly predict species richness, with the species-area relationship (S = cA^z) being one of the most robust patterns in ecology. Area is typically the stronger predictor because it affects both extinction rates (larger islands support larger populations less vulnerable to stochastic extinction) and habitat diversity. While species turnover has been more difficult to demonstrate convincingly, the species-area-distance predictions have been validated across numerous island systems, habitat fragments, and taxonomic groups.

questions.question: The Coriolis effect deflects moving air masses to the right in the Northern Hemisphere and to the left in the Southern Hemisphere. Which ecological phenomenon is a DIRECT consequence of this effect?
options: The existence of tropical rainforests at the equator
The stratification of lakes in temperate regions
The formation of permafrost in tundra biomes
The occurrence of coastal upwelling and nutrient-rich fisheries along certain coastlines
questions.explanation: The Coriolis effect directly drives coastal upwelling by deflecting surface waters away from certain coastlines. Along the western coasts of continents (e.g., California, Peru, West Africa), prevailing winds combined with Coriolis deflection push surface waters offshore. Deep, cold, nutrient-rich water rises to replace the surface water (upwelling), creating extremely productive marine ecosystems that support major fisheries. The Peru Current (Humboldt) upwelling zone, for example, produces more fish per unit area than almost any other ocean region. Without the Coriolis effect, there would be no systematic coastal upwelling and these highly productive zones would not exist.

questions.question: Ecotones are transition zones between adjacent biomes or ecosystems. Which prediction about ecotone biodiversity is MOST consistently supported by ecological theory and data?
options: Ecotones may have higher biodiversity than either adjacent biome due to the 'edge effect,' where species from both biomes overlap and unique edge-adapted species occur
Ecotones have lower biodiversity than either adjacent biome because they are suboptimal habitat for species from both biomes
Ecotones have identical species composition to the more productive of the two adjacent biomes
Ecotones act as barriers that prevent species movement between biomes, reducing overall landscape biodiversity
questions.explanation: Ecotones (transition zones between ecosystems) often exhibit the 'edge effect' — elevated biodiversity due to the overlap of species from both adjacent communities plus the presence of species specifically adapted to edge conditions. For example, a forest-grassland ecotone may contain forest interior species, grassland specialists, and edge-adapted species that exploit the unique conditions (e.g., higher light, more structural diversity) found at the boundary. However, this pattern is context-dependent: while many ecotones show elevated diversity, some act as barriers, and fragmentation-created edges can have negative effects on forest interior species that are edge-sensitive. The edge effect is most positive at natural ecotones and most negative at anthropogenic edges.

questions.question: The concept of biogeographic realms divides Earth's terrestrial surface into regions with distinct evolutionary histories and faunal assemblages. Which boundary between biogeographic realms is MOST abrupt, occurring across a narrow strait?
options: Wallace's Line between the Indomalayan and Australasian realms in Southeast Asia
The Nearctic-Neotropical boundary at the Isthmus of Panama
The Palearctic-Afrotropical boundary at the Sahara Desert
The Nearctic-Palearctic boundary at the Bering Strait
questions.explanation: Wallace's Line, running between Bali and Lombok and between Borneo and Sulawesi, marks one of the sharpest biogeographic boundaries on Earth. Despite the islands being only ~35 km apart in places, the fauna on either side is dramatically different. West of the line (Indomalayan realm) shows Asian affinity (e.g., monkeys, tigers, rhinoceroses), while east of the line (Australasian realm) shows Australasian affinity (e.g., marsupials, cockatoos). This sharp boundary exists because deep-water straits have separated these areas even during glacial periods of low sea level, when many other islands were connected by land bridges. The strait has been a barrier to dispersal for millions of years, allowing independent evolution on either side.

questions.question: A researcher hypothesizes that climate change is shifting plant hardiness zones northward. To detect this shift most reliably over a 30-year period, which data source would be MOST informative?
options: Annual mean temperature records from weather stations across a latitudinal gradient
Long-term phenological records (flowering dates, leaf-out dates) from citizen science networks spanning multiple decades
Satellite-derived vegetation indices (NDVI) tracking the latitudinal position of the forest-tundra boundary over time
Seed germination trials of southern species planted progressively northward each year
questions.explanation: Satellite-derived vegetation indices like NDVI provide the most reliable large-scale evidence of biome boundary shifts because they offer spatially continuous, consistent measurements over multi-decadal time periods. Satellite records (MODIS, Landsat) spanning 30+ years can detect changes in the latitudinal position of vegetation boundaries (such as the forest-tundra ecotone or the advance of shrubs into tundra) with high spatial resolution and standardized methodology. This approach overcomes the sampling limitations of weather stations (point measurements) and phenological networks (patchy coverage, observer bias). While temperature records (A) show climate change, they don't directly show ecological responses. Phenological records (B) are valuable but have gaps. Transplant experiments (D) are informative but limited in spatial scope.

questions.question:
Regarding adaptations of organisms to their abiotic environment, mark each statement as True (T) or False (F):
(I) CAM photosynthesis allows plants to fix CO2 at night, reducing water loss in arid environments
(II) Bergmann's rule states that body size increases with latitude in endotherms, which is an adaptation to conserve heat
(III) Counter-current heat exchangers in Arctic mammals warm venous blood returning from extremities to reduce heat loss
(IV) Hibernation in mammals involves complete cessation of metabolic activity until spring
options: TTFF
TTTF
TTFT
TFFF
questions.explanation: (I) TRUE — Crassulacean acid metabolism (CAM) plants open stomata only at night to fix CO2 into organic acids, which are then decarboxylated during the day to supply CO2 for the Calvin cycle with stomata closed. This dramatically reduces daytime water loss. (II) TRUE — Bergmann's rule describes the tendency for endotherm body size to increase with latitude and decreasing temperature. Larger body size produces a smaller surface area-to-volume ratio, reducing relative heat loss. (III) TRUE — Counter-current heat exchangers in the limbs of Arctic mammals (and birds) transfer heat from warm arterial blood to cool venous blood returning from extremities. This recaptures heat that would otherwise be lost and maintains core body temperature. (IV) FALSE — Hibernation involves dramatic reduction but not complete cessation of metabolism. Heart rate, breathing rate, and body temperature decrease substantially, but metabolic processes continue at a reduced rate. Periodic arousal episodes occur during hibernation.

questions.question: Oligotrophic lakes (low nutrient, clear water) and eutrophic lakes (high nutrient, turbid water) have fundamentally different ecological characteristics. Which metric BEST distinguishes between these lake types?
options: Total fish biomass, which is always higher in oligotrophic lakes due to better water quality
Secchi disk depth (water transparency), which reflects phytoplankton biomass driven by nutrient availability
Dissolved oxygen concentration at the surface, which is consistently higher in eutrophic lakes
Water temperature, as oligotrophic lakes are always colder than eutrophic lakes
questions.explanation: Secchi disk depth (a simple measure of water transparency) is the most practical and reliable metric for distinguishing lake trophic status. In oligotrophic lakes, low nutrient concentrations support minimal phytoplankton growth, resulting in clear water and high Secchi depths (>4 m). In eutrophic lakes, high nutrient concentrations (particularly phosphorus and nitrogen) support dense phytoplankton populations that make the water turbid and green, reducing Secchi depth (<2 m). While total phosphorus concentration is the most direct chemical indicator, Secchi depth integrates the biological response to nutrients and is easily measured. Fish biomass is actually higher in eutrophic lakes (more productivity), not oligotrophic. Surface DO can be high in eutrophic lakes (from photosynthesis), while hypolimnetic DO is low.

questions.question: Soil pH strongly influences plant nutrient availability. In acidic soils (pH < 5.5), which nutrient problem MOST commonly limits plant growth?
options: Iron becomes insoluble and unavailable for uptake
Aluminum becomes soluble and toxic to roots, while phosphorus becomes bound to aluminum and unavailable
Calcium concentrations become toxic, inhibiting root growth
Nitrogen fixation is enhanced, leading to nitrogen toxicity
questions.explanation: In acidic soils (pH < 5.5), two major problems limit plant growth. First, aluminum, which is abundant in soil minerals, becomes increasingly soluble at low pH and is toxic to plant roots — inhibiting root elongation, disrupting calcium uptake, and damaging root cell membranes. Second, phosphorus becomes largely unavailable because it forms insoluble complexes with the now-abundant aluminum (and iron) ions. This aluminum toxicity-phosphorus deficiency combination is the most common nutrient limitation in acid tropical soils (which comprise ~40% of tropical arable land). Liming (adding CaCO3) raises pH, precipitating aluminum and releasing phosphorus — this is one of the most important soil management practices in acid soils.

questions.question: In aquatic ecosystems, the compensation depth is the depth at which photosynthetic oxygen production equals respiratory oxygen consumption. Below this depth, net primary productivity is negative. What is the typical compensation depth in the clear tropical ocean?
questions.explanation: The compensation depth in clear tropical oceanic water typically ranges from 80-120 m. At this depth, light intensity has been attenuated to approximately 1% of surface irradiance (the '1% light level'), which is roughly the point where photosynthetic rate equals respiratory rate for phytoplankton. Above this depth (the photic or euphotic zone), net photosynthesis occurs; below it, respiration exceeds photosynthesis and organisms are net consumers of organic carbon. The compensation depth varies with water clarity: in turbid coastal waters, it may be only 5-20 m, while in the extremely clear open ocean, it can reach 100-120 m. The compensation depth defines the effective depth of the euphotic zone and therefore the depth to which primary production extends in the ocean.

questions.question: A climate diagram (Walter diagram) for a location shows monthly mean temperatures of 22-28C throughout the year, with precipitation of 250-350 mm/month from May-October and 5-20 mm/month from November-April. What biome would you predict, and what key ecological feature characterizes it?
options: Temperate deciduous forest with cold winters

Tropical seasonal forest/savanna with distinct wet and dry seasons—the pronounced dry season (November-April) drives seasonal leaf fall in deciduous trees, fire regimes that maintain grassland-savanna mosaics, and animal migrations tracking seasonal resource availability
Tundra with permafrost
Tropical rainforest with year-round precipitation
questions.explanation: Walter climate diagrams reveal biome-determining climate patterns: (1) Temperature profile: Consistently 22-28C indicates tropical location (no frost, minimal seasonal temperature variation). This eliminates temperate and boreal biomes. (2) Precipitation pattern: Strong seasonality with wet season (250-350 mm/month, May-Oct) and dry season (5-20 mm/month, Nov-Apr). Total annual rainfall ~1,600-2,200 mm but with 5-6 months of drought. (3) Biome prediction: This pattern characterizes tropical seasonal/deciduous forests and savannas. Total rainfall could support closed forest, but the prolonged dry season creates fire conditions that maintain open savanna. Where fire is excluded, tropical dry deciduous forest develops. (4) Ecological features: Deciduous trees shed leaves during dry season (conserving water). Fire is a key ecological process—frequent fires (every 1-5 years) maintain grass dominance; fire exclusion allows woody encroachment. Large herbivore migrations (Serengeti wildebeest) track spatial variation in seasonal rainfall. (5) On Walter diagrams, when the temperature line rises above the precipitation line, drought conditions exist—this gap indicates the dry season severity.

questions.question: A climatogram shows a location with mean annual temperature of 25°C, annual precipitation of 250 cm, and relatively uniform temperature year-round (range: 23-27°C). Which biome does this location MOST likely represent?
options: Tropical seasonal forest with distinct wet and dry seasons
Temperate rainforest with moderate temperatures and heavy rainfall
Subtropical desert with high temperatures and occasional monsoon rains
Tropical rainforest with consistent warmth and high, evenly distributed precipitation
questions.explanation: The combination of high mean annual temperature (25°C), extremely high annual precipitation (250 cm), and minimal seasonal temperature variation (23-27°C range) is diagnostic of a tropical rainforest. Tropical rainforests occur near the equator where solar input is high and relatively constant year-round, producing consistently warm temperatures. The high precipitation results from the convergence of trade winds at the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ), where rising warm air releases abundant moisture. Tropical seasonal forests would show greater precipitation variation, deserts have much lower rainfall, and temperate rainforests have lower temperatures.

questions.question: The concept of 'planetary boundaries' identifies nine Earth system processes with proposed safe operating limits for humanity. Which process has already exceeded its planetary boundary by the GREATEST margin?
options: Biodiversity loss (species extinction rate exceeding 10 extinctions per million species-years)
Climate change (atmospheric CO2 concentration exceeding 350 ppm)
Biogeochemical nitrogen cycle (annual industrial nitrogen fixation exceeding 62 Tg N/year)
Ocean acidification (aragonite saturation state declining below 2.75 in surface waters)
questions.explanation: According to the planetary boundaries framework (Rockstrom et al. 2009, updated by Steffen et al. 2015), biodiversity loss has exceeded its proposed safe boundary by the greatest margin of any planetary boundary. The background extinction rate is approximately 0.1-1 extinction per million species-years (E/MSY), and the proposed boundary was set at 10 E/MSY. Current estimated extinction rates are 100-1000 E/MSY — exceeding the boundary by a factor of 10-100. This places biodiversity loss firmly in the 'high-risk zone.' While climate change and the nitrogen cycle have also exceeded their boundaries, the margin of exceedance is smaller (atmospheric CO2 at ~420 ppm vs. boundary of 350 ppm = ~1.2x; industrial N fixation ~150 Tg/yr vs. boundary of 62 Tg/yr = ~2.4x). Biodiversity loss stands out as the most severely transgressed boundary.

questions.question: Streams and rivers show a predictable change in community structure from headwaters to mouth, described by the River Continuum Concept. In headwater streams (orders 1-3), what is the dominant source of organic carbon (energy) supporting the food web?
options: In-stream photosynthesis by periphyton (attached algae) growing on rocks
Allochthonous organic matter — leaf litter and other terrestrial plant material falling into the stream from riparian vegetation
Dissolved organic carbon carried by groundwater seeping into the stream
Phytoplankton suspended in the water column producing organic matter through photosynthesis
questions.explanation: The River Continuum Concept (Vannote et al., 1980) predicts that headwater streams (orders 1-3) are primarily fueled by allochthonous (externally derived) organic matter, mainly leaf litter from the surrounding riparian forest canopy. These narrow, shaded streams receive little direct sunlight, limiting in-stream photosynthesis. The dominant organic carbon source is coarse particulate organic matter (CPOM) — leaves, twigs, and other plant material — that falls or is blown into the stream. This CPOM is processed by 'shredder' macroinvertebrates that break it into fine particulate organic matter (FPOM), which is then transported downstream to feed 'collectors' in mid-order reaches. In wider, mid-order streams (4-6), the canopy opens and in-stream photosynthesis becomes the dominant energy source.
